awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Cultural Conceptions of the Nature and Management of Solid Waste
awd_abstract_narration:
The monitoring, treatment, and disposition of solid waste is one of the many daunting challenges associated with economic development and population growth.  Waste management practices vary widely around the world. Culture, social systems, economics, politics, and even religion affect what is classified as waste in the first place, what sites and methods are deemed suitable for waste disposal, and how people can be motivated to comply with regulations. Appropriate waste management is critical to sustaining eco-system services and protecting public health but successful solutions require more than improved technology.

In this research project, University of Wisconsin doctoral student Bo Wang, with the guidance of Dr. Yongming Zhou, will become one of the first researchers to look at how the many factors affecting solid waste management come together in a non-Western context. The researcher will travel to Yunnan Province in Southwest China to carry out a 12 month, ethnographic investigation in three sites: two mountain villages where tourism and pilgrimage to a sacred religious site have generated large amounts of solid waste and, in the same region, a newly established modern landfill that employs hundreds of local people in this new industry. In all three sites, solid waste is intimately intertwined with people's daily lives.  Relying primarily on participant observation and interviews, the project will elucidate (1) what tourists, pilgrims, government staff, and environmental and religious groups conceive of as waste and not-waste; and (2) how waste affects and is affected by the delineation of sacred sites and tourism.  Findings from this research will contribute to developing cross-culturally valid theories of how human beings understand their role in the natural and material world as well as provide critically needed information for the development of effective global programs for solid waste management.

This project studied the Tibetan cultural notion of garbage and the dynamics between notions of garbage and sacredness, as well as the cultural process that shapes the understanding of garbage in Tibetan sacred mountains located in Southwest China. Although the logistics and costs of garbage may be well calculated by the science of garbage management, the cultural notions of garbage, crucial to everyday garbage management, remained obscure. Thus, situated in the cultural work that breaks the monolithic view of garbage, this project examined the Tibetan garbage and sacred mountains in Khawa Kharpo and Shangri-La, China in the past two decades when China’s explosive tourist boom had made garbage the greatest challenge on the Tibetan sacred mountains at the Third Pole. It asked how the making of garbage and the making of sacred peaks corresponded to the varied everyday practice by multiple actors, including the Tibetan villagers, Chinese tourists, and local government officials in bureaus of environment and religion during this period of time. The project selected those three groups because they lived in, toured around, and managed the sacred mountains and garbage, thereby having developed their own distinct categories of garbage and the understanding of garbage and sacredness. In studying the contestation and negotiation in these groups, this project grounded the enactment of sacredness on the Tibetan landscape that was increasingly touristized and scientifically managed, especially teasing out the everyday yearning for inner purification of those Tibetans between a mindful and lively land and a marketized world.

Relying on participant observation, day-to-day interaction, and in-depth interviews, this project sought to investigate three major processes that contributed to make garbage and sacredness real to everyday life: categories, senses, and entangled lives. First was on the categories of waste objects vis-à-vis sacred deposits. The appearance of discarded plastic water bottles, metal cans, papers, and carefully placed prayer flags, necklaces, clothes was prevalent on the Khawa Kharpo sacred mountains. Although the contrast between two groups of objects were clear to trained eyes with a Tibetan wisdom of sacredness, it was largely absent for most Chinese tourists and local government officials that developed and adapted to the newly introduced category “municipal solid waste” from a scientific management approach. This difference was generated by the unequal status of knowledge systems as well as differentiated access to decision-making. The understanding of a lively and mindful landscape where sacred and waste objects transformed into each other was undermined. Second line of investigation was on the senses through which people made sense of purification and dirt in their everyday routine. In Shangri-La City where temple goers and city garbage management crew frequented every day, loudspeakers occupied central sensorium of residents and visitors. Whereas loudspeakers appeared rare in most other parts of China, these devices were pervasive here, even though for those middle-aged they marked recent histories of socialist state violence and state’s tight grip on public life of individuals. Broadcasting about garbage policies in the temples, playing ethnic music for dances on the square, or speaking Buddhist sutras in the town center, those loudspeakers constituted sensorium for local people to make sense of ongoing making of a city that was supposed to be both clean and sacred. Third investigation was on individual actors’ role in creating an indigenous space for making garbage management work and simultaneously making sacred traditions alive.
